aYPtWVpN.question: Which option most accurately describes essential aerodrome information?

nBeSFz4F.question:
You are in flight, approaching Otopeni, the destination aerodrome, and have received the following ATIS broadcast. To which ATS unit do you need to acknowledge the receipt of this ATIS, and on what frequency?
"OTOPENI INFORMATION OSCAR. 
TIME 1250. 
EXPECT AN ILS APPROACH
ARRIVALS RUNWAY 08 RIGHT, DEPARTURES RUNWAY 08 LEFT.
TRANSITION ALTITUDE 4000 FT.
WORK IN PROGRESS ON APRON TWO.
SURFACE WIND 250, 14 KNOTS.
VISIBILITY 10 KILOMETRES OR MORE.
SCATTERED 2400 FT, BROKEN 4600 FT.
CUMULONIMBUS DETECTED.
TEMPERATURE +19, DEW POINT +4.
QNH 1007.
NO SIGNIFICANT CHANGE.
ACKNOWLEDGE RECEIPT OF INFORMATION OSCAR WITH APP ON 119.415.
DEPARTURE WITH DELIVERY ON 121.955."

5000 m, and the lowest visibility is not reported

N8pkOTaV.question:
You are approaching an ATS reporting point.
 The controller has instructed you to make routine meteorological reports, the last of which was approximately one hour ago.
 You experience turbulence, which makes occupants feel strain against the seat belts.
 As required by the Standardised European Rules of the Air (SERA), you should:

options.text: make a special air report and omit the routine report.
make the routine report at the reporting point but, since the turbulence is only moderate, it can be excluded from the report.
include the information in the routine report, which should be made in approximately one hour.
include the information in the routine report due at the reporting point.

EZ2uWy5e.question:

 During the flight in the cruise, with approximately 500 NM to go, the pilot wishes to check the destination weather. Where/how could this information be obtained?

options.text: D-ATIS by using Satcom and data link equipment such as ACARS.
The scheduled VOLMET on Super High Frequencies (SHF).
ATIS using the designated frequency of an airport en-route, on Very High Frequencies (VHF).

TAeHcvTK.question: An aircraft is flying at a cruise altitude of 9 000 ft and at a distance of about 100 nm from its destination the pilot wants to listen to the ATIS. The message is very distorted and only parts of it can be received. What should the pilot do in order to have better reception?

options.text: Fly at a higher altitude to increase the range of the reception.
Increase the volume of the receiver.
Increase the volume of his/her headset.
Select the frequency of APPROACH because they are responsible for the higher airspace.
